Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a research project at the interface of number theory, representation theory, and theoretical physics. Recent work of the investigator and collaborators has shown that certain matrices, known as R-matrices, that arise in theoretical physics in the study of statistical mechanics and phase transitions also arise in the study of a class of functions, known as Whittaker functions, that encode arithmetic information when these functions are viewed representation-theoretically, that is, when inherent algebraic symmetries are taken into account. This discovery opens the door to a rich collection of questions that will be explored in this project. It is anticipated that in the process, important new connections between number theory and mathematical physics will be developed.

In more detail, Whittaker functions on p-adic groups are a fundamental tool in automorphic forms. Whittaker functions on metaplectic covers of these groups are less well-understood, but the corresponding matrices on intertwining operators have been computed. The investigator and collaborators have shown that these matrices for the n-fold mataplectic cover of GL(n) agree with the R-matrices for a quantum group, which is a Drinfield twist of the quantized enveloping algebra of the affinized Lie superalgebra gl(1/n). The effect of the Drinfield twisting is to introduce Gauss sums into the R-matrix, and therefore to make it "number-theoretic." This clarifies a great deal, but also presents new questions that will be explored in this project. A separate but related project that will be pursued is an on-going study of connections between unique models and representations of Hecke algebras.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This project concerned new connections between the theory of quantum groups, a topic originating in mathematical physics, and the representation theory of p-adic groups, a topic originating in number theory. These were investigated by Bump in collaboration with Brubaker, Buciumas, Friedberg and Gustafsson, resulting in three breakthroughs in our understanding, which have resulted in several papers. In another line, Bump and his student Aboumrad have been working on ideas, also related to quantum groups, with potential application to quantum computing.

Solvable lattice models originated in statistical mechanics but within mathematical physics, they also have connections to quantum physics and (recently) the emerging field of integrable probability, represented by the work of Borodin and his collaborators. On the other hand, Whittaker functions arise in both number theory and physics but focussing on the number-theoretic aspects, their theory has been important in automorphic forms and the Langlands program. 

The applications to the representation theory of p-adic groups originated around 2010 with Bump and his collaborators (Brubaker, Chinta, Friedberg and Gunnells). At the beginning of this grant, the connection seemed very promising but the situation was unsatisfactory because there were important things we did not know how to do. The program involved representing Whittaker functions as partition functions of solvable lattice models, bringing in a new tool to the theory, the Yang-Baxter equation. To more fully capture the richness of the representation theory of p-adic groups, the theory as it existed prior to this grant needed to be expanded in two different ways: to include the theory of metaplectic groups, and to include the theory of Iwahori Whittaker functions. These expansions of the theory were accomplished during the grant period, and they required new ideas. The new models are unexpectedly rich "supersymmetric", and also use a notion of color, borrowed from Borodin and Wheeler's work in integrable probability. This was accomplished in two papers. Two more papers concerned other aspects of these ideas: an application to algebraic combinatorics and a connection with vertex operators, a tool originating in string theory.

In a separate work, Bump and Nakasuji made a new connection between the representation theory of p-adic groups and Kazhdan-Lusztig theory, a theory with surprising connections to different areas of mathematics. This took the form of two conjectures, which were later refined by Naruse and proved by Aluffi, Mihalcea and Su using methods from algebraic geometry. Currently Bump is working with Beatrice Chetard to generalize these conjectures.

In another work with Brubaker, Buciumas and Friedberg, Bump investigated connections between unique functionals on p-adic groups (arising from subgroups of the group) and models such as Whittaker functions. This resulted in one paper.

Broader Impacts:

During this grant, Bump co-organized a conference at ETH and is currently co-organizing (with Friedberg, Green, Kleinschmidt, Persson and Wendland) a program at the Newton Institute (postponed to 2022 due to the COVID19 pandemic). The ETH conference had an important component of supporting early career mathematicians. Bump, with his student Aboumrad added code to work with Verlinde fusion algebras to Sagemath mathematical software; this will potentially be of use to researchers in topological quantum computing. At the beginning of the grant period, Bump was completing his book with Anne Schilling on crystal bases, a book that has been helpful to students of the field. During the grant period, Bump has mentored three graduate students.
